mode_not.content2: You can compare antihistamines or decongestants using our comparison table to see which will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Prevent exposure    

Obviously, if you don't want to have symptoms, you will take preventing exposure to allergens seriously. 

  • Get an app that shows you the pollen calendar and pollen counts in your area. 
    Use this as a guide to  prepare for outside activities. 
  • Use allergy mask or something similar if you need to mow the lawn or do some gardening.
  • Smear petroleum jelly in the nasal passages when outdoors to trap pollen and prevent it from getting to the inner lining of the nose.
  • Wear sunglasses when outdoors if the pollen count is high.
  • Keep windows closed. 

 Intranasal steroids

This is the most effective preventive treatment. It is also the best choice if symptoms are moderate to severe.

The real benefit comes with daily use. Better to start about a week before the allergy season starts. 

Know that you can start it anytime, but  you will get some symptoms relief within a day, but full beneficial effect may take up to 7 days of daily use.

The goal for you is to use it daily until the allergy season is over for effective and enjoyable allergy season.

Antihistamine

Take first thing in the morning before you step outside for effective prevention. I personally take mine right after brushing my teeth. It may get hectic with the kids and all and I may forget to take it.

Remember, you have to get the antihistamine in there to block the histamine receptors before the histamine starts causing havoc.

collapsable.title: Decongestants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
A decongestant will help ease the blocked or stuffy nose.

Decongestants cause the blood vessels in the lining of the nose and sinuses to narrow, thereby reducing the stuffy nose or sinus congestion.

 

An antihistamine will not reduce stuffy nose. It will only help if it is runny. 

A decongestant will not help with a runny nose only if it is congested or blocked.

 

With this in mind, you may need a combination of both an antihistamine and a decongestant if you alternate between a runny and a stuffy nose.

 

Tap on the "FYI" below for a good way to choose a decongestant that will work best for you.

If you have time, check out this new acne cream. We think you may find it useful. Take a look.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Contact with an allergen, a foreign substance like pollen, is causing the mast cells in the nose, eyes, throat  to release more histamine than usual.​

This is causing the itchy eyes, throat, runny nose, sneezing, red, watery eyes  you are experiencing. 

 

An antihistamine blocks histamine from reaching the cells to cause these symptoms. 

This is why antihistamines are most effective when taken before you come in contact with the allergen.

Be sure to compare antihistamines using our comparison table to see which will work best for you. A quick link to the comparison table is given at the end of this page.

Testing a gif banner from google

Your interaction with this ad supports us. Thank you.
Save Ad For Interaction Later

Learn More Got It

collapsable.title: Pain / Fever reducer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Inflammation and swelling of the sinuses and severe nasal congestion can lead to sinus pressure causing headaches and facial or sinus pain.

It is usually better to take a decongestant along with a pain relief medication for a headache or sinus pain.

 

You need to take care of the underlying cause of this pain before it will really go away.

Acetaminophen is preferred if it is just a headache.

Ibuprofen or naproxen is preferred if you have inflammation of the sinuses causing facial pain with a headache.
These also have anti-inflammatory properties compared to acetaminophen.

collapsable.title: Cough Relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Mucus dripping down the throat from the back of the nose (post nasal drip) will trigger the cough reflex.

We normally will not recommend a cough medication. Because if you do not take care of what is causing it, you will keep coughing.

Here are situations that will warrant getting a cough medicine:

  • A cough is waking you up at night.
    Dextromethorphan will  suppress the cough for a good night's sleep. 
    Diphenhydramine or doxylamine can suppress the cough while making you sleep.  
     
  • Mucus has accumulated giving a feeling of chest congestion.
    You will need to thin the mucus so you can cough it out.
    Guaifenesin with drinking a lot of water should help with this.

collapsable.title: Allergy Relief Eye Drops click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Just as allergens getting to the nose triggers a runny itchy nose, pollen or other allergens getting to the surface of the eyes can trigger histamine release leading to itchy, watery and even swollen eyes.

You will need an antihistamine eye drops.

 

First choice
ketotifen fumarate opthalmic solution. This work for up to 12 hours on a single dose and is more effective.

 

Second choice
Eye drops that end with a capital "A".  Naphcon A, visine A, opcon A and so on. 
They last for 4 to 6 hours. So you may have to carry them with you.
Choose this if the first choice is too expensive for you.

 

See the product comparison section of this app for a good way to choose an allergy relief eye drops.

collapsable.title: Steroidal Nasal Sprays click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Intranasal steroids (INS) have anti-inflammatory properties.

The inside of your nose can easily become inflamed as a result of pollen or other allergens.

A steroidal nasal spray will relieve  symptoms like a runny nose, stuffy nose, sneezing, itchy nose by reducing and preventing this inflammation.

 

They are recommended for moderate to severe allergic rhinitis.  Now, how do you know you have moderate to severe allergic rhinitis?

You know if symptoms are:

  • getting more difficult to tolerate.
  • getting so bad that it is hard to function at school, home or work.
  • interfering with your sleep.
  • making you change antihistamines because one is no longer working as good.
  • making you put off activities like mowing, gardening or sports.

If any one of these applies to you, add intranasal steroids to your regimen.  

A good example is  triamcinolone acetonide, fluticasone nasal spray.

collapsable.title: Multi-Symptoms click to expand contents
Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Allergy mask    

Wear an allergy mask if you are going to mow the lawn, work in the garden do other outside chores around the house. You will be surprised to see how much it helps.

Shower    

Those green or yellow pollen sitting on your car during allergy season, they are also on your hair. You need to wash more often. 

Your hair attracts more pollen than you can imagine. This include changing clothes more often.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registegreen US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressugreen to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answegreen and not stogreen in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authogreen. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.top_header:
Ewe,
Let's get something for this cold.

There is no cure for the common cold.
What you can do is:

  • take care of the symptoms with over-the-counter medications

  • reduce it's ability to limit your daily activities

  • reduce the duration of the cold

  • prevent any complications.
tabs.header: The most common symptoms of a cold are listed below. Choose what you are experiencing and see what we recommend.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

If you think you have a cold:

Please go back and choose the symptom(s) that you feel closely relate to what you have or might have had and let me recommend something for you.

Remember, there is no cure for the common cold. All we can do is manage the symptoms if you have one.

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 12:16:am
mode_not.content2: We can help you compare over the counter multi-symptom cold medications that will work best for you if you need help with that.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
collapsable.content:
Definitely:    ​

  • Wash the hands often.
  • Use alcohol-based hand sanitizers if water is not available.
  • If your school-age child sneezes, have him or her wash hands immediately. Don't be lazy about this. Just one quick sneeze is enough to make you sick. 

Over-The-Counter Medicines:

We strongly recommend the cold prevention medicines comparison feature of this app. (See link below).

collapsable.title: Decongestants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Start with a decongestant nasal spray.

Prefer nasal spray containing oxymetazoline. These last for up to 12 hours.
Those containing phenylephrine need to be used every 4 to 6 hours.
 

After 3 to 5 days, if you are still congested, switch to pseudoephedrine tablets. Continuing the spray will lead to a cycle of rebounding nasal congestion. Don't be tempted to use the nasal spray for more than 5 days. Take this seriously or you will be in for a nasal congestion ride of your life. How do you know if you are in the rebound phase? If a decongestant nasal spray that used to give you relief for 12 hrs, became 10hrs and now it is 8 hrs. Stop.
 

We do not recommend phenylephrine tablets. Don't waste your money. If you want to breathe at night, go to the pharmacy counter and ask for pseudoephedrine tablets. Take a government issued ID with you.

If you can't take pseudoephedrine tablets or the congestion is not so bad, continue with saline nasal spray.

Before we continue, our sponsor would like to share something we think you should know about.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
The first generation antihistamines - chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine or diphenhydramine work better for cold. They will make you sleepy, however.

Do not use non-sedating antihistamines like Claritin, Allegra or Zyrtec when it comes to cold. They are only useful in allergy situations.

If you have other symptoms, look for multisymptom medications with chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine,  diphenhydramine or doxylamine.

Use the "FYI" button below for a good way to compare multisymptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Pain / Fever reducer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Prefer acetaminophen if what you are experiencing is mainly headache along with other cold symptoms like runny nose and nasal congestion.
 

Prefer ibuprofen or naproxen if muscle ache and pain, sinus pain or sinus pressure due to inflamed sinuses.
These have anti-inflammatory properties. Unlike acetaminophen.

collapsable.title: Cough Relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Suppressing the cough    

Use a cough suppressant if:

  • this cough is keeping you up at night 
  • this is a dry cough with no mucus being produced. 
  • this cough is giving you chest pain.     

If none of these, stay away from a cough suppressant.    ​

Postnasal drip (mucus dripping to the back of the throat) is causing most of the coughing by triggering the cough reflex. This is the body's attempt to clear the air passages and prevent mucus from getting to the lungs. If you take a cough suppressant, this preventive mechanism is suppressed leading to a higher potential for secondary upper respiratory tract infections.

Dextromethorphan is the cough suppressant available besides menthol in cough drops. There are different formulations, so see "FYI" below for how to choose a good cough suppressant that will work best for you.

Expectorant    

With time, mucus accumulates in the sinuses and nasal passages. This can become thick reducing its flow.

Mucus in the body should be thin and flow easily as it moistens the lining of the sinuses, respiratory tract and remove bacteria, viruses, dust, pollen and other foreign substances.
 

Thick mucus is bad because it traps bacteria, viruses and dirt and does not flow easily and quickly enough for the body to get rid of it either by swallowing it or coughing it up and out.
 

An expectorant will break up, loosen and thin the mucus making it flow more easily for you to expectorate (bring it up and out).    
 

Must drink a lot of water for it to work effectively.

Guaifenesin is the most common expectorant.   

 

Combination or not?

Get a combination (Guaifenesin DM) if you have chest congestion and coughing is getting violent or giving you chest pain.

You will experience this during the last stage of the cold because the mucus has dried up triggering the cough reflex and it is not flowing leading to coughing spells.

Guaifenesin with drinking a lot of water will break this up and get the mucus flowing again while dextromethorphan will help control the coughing spells until the mucus stops triggering this cough reflex.

collapsable.title: Multi-Symptom click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Choosing a multi-symptoms cold medicine    ​

The best thing to do is to use the comparison feature of this app. (See link below).    

What to look out for:    ​

  • Make sure other medicine you are taking does not contain acetaminophen. Most multi-symptom will contain acetaminophen.
  • Don't expect them to relieve nasal congestion even if it says so on the box. Except you buy the ones kept behind the pharmacy counter.
  • We don't really recommend these because cold comes in different stages. You have to treat the symptom at that stage or you are wasting your money. For instance, the last stage is usually the coughing and chest congestion phase. Buying a multisymptom with cough suppressants or expectorants earlier, may be a waste of money.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Invest in a humidifier

The air is dry which in turn dries up the nasal passages and need to be moisturized.

We recommend cool mist.    

Warm mist is too dangerous especially if you have children in the house. Moreover, by the time the moisture gets from the air to your nasal passages, it is already cold.

Warm mist is also more expensive.

If you really need a warm mist, put your head over a bowl of hot water to inhale the vapors. Or better yet, take a hot shower. 

High vitamin and mineral concentrations

Take any of the high vitamin and mineral containing tablets or packets that you dissolve in water before drinking. Examples include  Airborne® or Emergency C®.
These work 50% of the time to reduce the severity of the cold symptoms.

But stay away from the ones you spray in your mouth. Some taste like urine. The taste of zinc can be hard to mask.

Drink plenty of water

More so if you have chest congestion. You need to thin the mucus so it will keep moving.

collapsable.title: How this recommendation work click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Decongestants:
I recommended pseudoephedrine. This work by....

If you don't have an ID, I recommended a nasal spray. This work by ...

Antihistamines:
I recommended either chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine or doxylamine.
These are called first generation antihistamines. They work by...

Neti pot / Alkalol / Saline:
This work by...

Guaifenesin, humidifiers, zinc

collapsable.title: How to use what is recommended click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Decongestants:

Pseudoephedrine:

  • 30 mg tabs:
    Take 2 tablets every 4 to 6 hours. Max of 8 tablets in 24 hours. (Take this maximum number seriously)
  • 12 hour tablets (120mg):
    Take 1 tablet every 12 hours. (Doesn't have to be exactly 12 hours. Anywhere between 10 and 12 hrs is okay). Fit in the evening dose before 7 pm so you won't be awake all night.

tabs.top_header:
Ewe,
Take a look at what is recommended for flu symptoms.

 

There is no cure for the flu. What you can do is:

  • Take care of the symptoms

  • Reduce it's ability to limit your daily activities

  • Reduce the duration of the flu

  • Prevent any complications.

FYI


Before you continue, see what our sponsors want to share with you. We think it is a good idea.

mode.29: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, pain / fever and stomach relief medications.
mode.30: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.31: Need an antihistamine, stomach relief, Pain / fever with expectorant / cough suppressant medications.
mode.32: Symptoms require a decongestant, stomach, pain / fever and expectorant with or cough suppressant relief medications.
mode.33: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, stomach an expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.34:
Okay.
You must have this flu pretty bad.

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 01:50:pm
mode_not.content2: You can compare over the counter multi-symptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Preventive measures click to collapse contents
collapsable.content:
1. The best way to prevent getting the flu illness is a flu shot. Early October is best, but any time is good.

Look for quadrivalent vaccines. It should cost nothing if you have health insurance. 

2. Frequent hand wash and use a hand sanitizer in the absence of water to wash the hands. Keep a small bottle in the bag, car, and office. Flu virus can stay on surfaces for hours.

collapsable.title: Decongestants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
They reduce swelling of the small blood vessels inside the nose, sinuses and throat.

 

Start with the nasal spray. This provides immediate relief. If after 4 days you are still feeling stuffed up, switch to the tablets.

You should not use the spray for more than 4, maximum 5 days. Take this seriously or else you would get into a circle of rebound congestion and it is not fun.​

If a nasal spray that used to give you 10 to 12 hours of relief is now giving you 8 hours or less, then it is time to stop. You are now in the rebound phase.

 

Talking about the tablet, do not take decongestants containing phenylephrine. This does not work.

Go to the pharmacy counter and ask for pseudoephedrine. Requires a government issued ID. Go through this extra step if you want to breathe.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Histamine is released if the immune system detects a harmful foreign object like a virus, bacteria, pollen, dust or your skin is damaged by an insect bite or something.

This cause the surrounding small blood vessels to expand, leak fluid, irritate surrounding nerves leading to a runny nose, sneezing, mucus production and so on.

So you will need an antihistamine.

These coat receptor sites for histamine in the cells so that histamine release will not activate these cells.

For flu symptoms, the first generation antihistamines like diphenhydramine, chlorpheniramine, clemastine are useful.

Stay away from loratadine, fexofenadine, or cetirizine. These do not help with a runny nose due to flu symptoms.

 

Multisymptom products are the best way to go if you also have this runny nose with other flu symptoms.

Compare multi-symptom cold and flu products using the link at the end of this page.

collapsable.title: Pain / Fever reducer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Usually with the flu, you will have body aches, headaches, joint pain and fever.

Which pain or fever reducing medicine should you choose? Acetaminophen, ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin?

 

If fever is the main concern, go with acetaminophen.

If muscle pain, go with ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin. These have anti-inflammatory properties, unlike acetaminophen.

If a headache is a major problem, go with acetaminophen. It works better with headaches.

If it is a sore throat, go with either one, but we particularly like  Tylenol® Cold Cool Burst  due to the way it is formulated to help with a sore throat. Pay the extra money to get the brand name. Store brands do not work the same here.

Keep this in mind when choosing multi symptoms products.

collapsable.title: Cough Relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Thick and dried mucus may have accumulated in the chest.

You will have to loosen the mucus, moisturize and expectorate it (cough it out) so the chest will start feeling less congested.

First step:
Break up or loosen the gunk so it will start flowing again.

To do this:

  1. Drink lots of water.
  2. Moisturize the airways to loosen this dried mucus.
    Use a humidifier or a cool mist vaporizer. If you don't have one, don't go running to the store to buy one. Just stick your head over a pot of warm water that has steam coming out or better yet, take a hot shower.

    Cold viruses thrive in dry conditions like winter. Moisturizing the airways will help get rid of them quicker.    

Second:     

Need an expectorant.
Guaifenesin is the ingredient to look for in a cough syrup or tablet.

If  a cough is keeping you up at night,  add "DM" dextromethorphan. This is a cough suppressant.
 

Tap on "FYI" below for the best way to choose a cough medication that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Multi-Symptoms click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Use the comparison section of this app to compare multi-symptom flu medications.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. Drink plenty of water.    

 

2. CDC recommends that you stay home for at least 24 hours after your fever is gone except to get medical care or for other necessities. More tips from CDC.  

  

3. Call the doctor for Tamiflu to protect the rest of the family.

4. Wash your hands often and use hand sanitizers often.

collapsable.title: Our disclaimer click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Recommendation is the opinion of a registered US Pharmacist currently practicing as a community pharmacist.
  • Recommendation is not an attempt to discuss all possible self care or treatment approach to this health challenge.
  • The responsibility of the recommending pharmacist is limited to this question:
    "If a patient presents with these symptoms, what will you recommend and why?"
    It is not an attempt to publish an article on the treatment of any condition. Just what would you tell a patient who present with so and so in the usual course of your practice.
  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.
  • Please read the policies and terms of use for self-care OTC, selfcarepharmacist.com and it's affiliates by clicking on the button below.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header:
Ewe,
Let's figure out something over the counter for this headache.

Tap on the type of headache you think you are experiencing and see what is recommended to use over the counter.

ullist.text:
Tension

Dull, pressure-like pain.
Like a tight band around my head

Migraine

Pulsating, throbbing pain
Very sensitive to light, sound

Sinus

Pain, pressure in forehead
Worse when I bend down

Others

Hangover, premenstrual.

mode.1: Over the counter recommendation for tension headaches are discussed below.
mode.2: Over the counter recommendations for migraine headaches are discussed below.
mode.3: Take a look at over the counter recommendations for sinus headaches discussed below.
mode.4:
Over the counter recommendations for other types of headaches include:

 

Need treatment overview entry here

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/25/2016 at 03:07:am

collapsable.title: Acetaminophen click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Acetaminophen is usually better for headaches compared with NSAIDS or others. 

It may be better to combine it with caffeine to help boost its effectiveness.

Another advantage is that it won't tear up your stomach as with NSAIDS. Usually, when you have a headache, you just want to lie down somewhere. Doing this can cause heartburn after taking something like ibuprofen. If you are prone to heartburn, go with acetaminophen.

collapsable.title: NSAIDs click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These are anti-inflammatory pain relievers used to relieve headaches and other types of pain.

First choice of NSAIDS:    ​    

Ibuprofen or buffered aspirin. Choose this if you can take it. See the 'know this' section to see who should not take it  and the side effects to expect.    ​

Others:

Naproxen

collapsable.title: Caffeine + Pain reliever    click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Acetaminophen + caffeine  

This will provide quick relief for the head, neck and shoulder pain associated with most tension headaches.

The caffeine helps boost the effectiveness of acetaminophen for the headache.

The only catch, try not to take this late in the night because of the caffeine. The amount in 2 capsules is equivalent to a cup of coffee.

collapsable.title: Pain reliever + PM click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Acetaminophen PM

This is a good choice for a late night or at bedtime headaches.

They contain diphenhydramine (Benadryl). The goal is to ease your headache while getting you some sleep.

Ibuprofen PM

This is a good choice if you also have body aches and other sore muscles with this headache. 

But do not take this if you get frequent heartburn or other stomach irritation problems. You will wake up bloated in the morning with a headache coming back soon after.

collapsable.title: Worth doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
1. If you are prone to tension headaches and anticipate coming down with one because of a stressful day or hectic activity, take acetaminophen or an NSAID before hand.

2. If your tension headache is due to stress or anxiety. Take valerian with the headache medication before you go to sleep.

3. Remember to rest with an ice bag over your forehead.

collapsable.title: Acetaminophen click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Acetaminophen is a non-specific medication for a migraine. That is it works on all kinds of headaches. 

You may want to take this in a combination form. Like combined with caffeine and aspirin.

collapsable.title: NSAIDS click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
These are anti-inflammatory pain relievers. They can be effective for headaches in general and are worth a try in migraine headaches. 

Ibuprofen and naproxen are good examples. 

Remember, over-the-counter medicines are no substitute for prescription migraine medicines. Those are more specific and work much better. You should only use OTC medicines in the absence of prescription migraine medicines. It is very necessary you treat your migraine immediately with the medicine prescribed by your physician.

collapsable.title: Worth Doing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
We assume you know what your triggers are by now. If not, this is the first thing to do. Try including these in your migraine therapy. They should help.

1. You must see a doctor for migraine headaches. Make sure you always have enough supply of your doctor's recommended medication on hand. It is hard enough to find which prescription medicine will work for you, when you find one, do your best to have it with you. Just a reminder, if a medicine prescribed is not working for you, call the doctor to try something else. Taking more won't make any difference.

2. Keep a headache journal. It is important you know how you respond to migraine medicines. Which one worked best for you? What triggered it? How bad is this migraine? These are questions you need to know as time goes on.

3. Know your triggers. Prevention is better than cure. Moreover, prescription migraine medications are not cheap. You need to be more focused on prevention and use those medicines only when you need them.

collapsable.title: NSAIDS click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Non-Steroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDS) include ibuprofen, naproxen, aspirin. We recommend this for sinus pain and pressure. Most of the time, inflammation of the sinuses would lead to a headache. NSAIDS helps with the inflammation while working on the head pain.​

If this headache also includes severe sinus pressure, you will be better off adding pseudoephedrine to relieve the pressure. Good combinations are available behind the pharmacy counter. Ibuprofen + pseudoephedrine; Naproxen + pseudoephedrine are good examples. If the pharmacy is closed, a nasal spray with oxymetazoline will help. But use this as a last resort.

collapsable.title: Acetaminophen click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
We recommend acetaminophen if you can't take NSAIDS. If all you have is a headache, acetaminophen will be better. For instance a lingering headache after a sinus infection. In this case, acetaminophen will be appropriate.

If you cannot take NSAIDS and think acetaminophen will work better for you, we encourage you to combine it with pseudoephedrine which is available behind the pharmacy counter. This combination will be useful in a case of headache with sinus pain and pressure.
